question: Question 1 The output expression for the Karnaugh map shown below is
solution: [latex]F=A+\bar{C}[/latex]

question: Question 2 The circuit shown below is an example of a
solution: [latex]\frac{V_{out}}{V_{in}}=-\left [\frac{\frac{ R_2\cdot \frac{1}{j\omega C}}{R_2+\frac{1}{j\omega C}}}{R_1} \right ][/latex] [latex] \frac{V_{out}}{V_{in}}=-\left [ \frac{R_2}{R_1(R_2j\omega C+1)} \right ][/latex] So the system is a low pass filter.

question: Question 3 The following figure shows the connection of an ideal transformer with primary to secondary turns ratio of 1:100. The applied primary voltage is 100 V (rms), 50 Hz, AC. The rms value of the current I, in ampere, is __________.
solution: The above circuit can be drown by transferring secondary circuit to primary side. [latex]I=\frac{100V}{(8+10j-4j)\Omega }[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{100V}{(8+6j)\Omega }[/latex] So the rms value of I will be 10 A.

question: Question 4 Consider a causal LTI system characterized by differential equation [latex]\frac{dy(t)}{dt}+\frac{1}{6}y(t)=3x(t)[/latex]. The response of the system to the input [latex]x(t)=3e^{-\frac{t}{3}}u(t)[/latex]. where u(t) denotes the unit step function, is
solution: The differential equation [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{dy(t)}{dt} &+\frac{1}{6}y(t)=3x(t) \\ \text{So, }sY(s)&+\frac{1}{6}Y(s) =3X(s) \\ Y(s) &=\frac{3X(s)}{\left ( s+\frac{1}{6} \right )} \\ X(s) &=\frac{9}{\left ( s+\frac{1}{3} \right )} \\ \text{So, } Y(s)&=\frac{9}{\left ( s+\frac{1}{3} \right )\left ( s+\frac{1}{6} \right )} \\ &=\frac{54}{\left ( s+\frac{1}{6} \right )} -\frac{54}{\left ( s+\frac{1}{3} \right )}\\ \text{So, }y(t) &= (54e^{-1/6t}-54e^{-1/3t})u(t) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 5 Suppose the maximum frequency in a band-limited signal [latex]x(t)[/latex] is 5 kHz. Then, the maximum frequency in [latex]x(t)\cos (2000\pi t)[/latex], in kHz, is ________.
solution: Maximum possible frequency of [latex]x(t)(2000 \pi t)=f_1+f_2=5+1=6kHz[/latex]

question: Question 6 Consider the function [latex]f(z)=z+z^*[/latex] where z is a complex variable and [latex]z^*[/latex] denotes its complex conjugate. Which one of the following is TRUE?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(z) &=z+z^* \\ f(z)&=2x \text{ is continuous (polynomial)} \\ u &=2x, v=0 \\ u_x &=2, u_y=0 \\ v_x&=0, v_y=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] C.R. equation not satisfied. Therefore, no where analytic.

options.A: f(z) is both continuous and analytic
options.B: f(z) is continuous but not analytic
options.C: f(z) is not continuous but is analytic
options.D: f(z) is neither continuous nor analytic

question: Question 7 A 3 x 3 matrix P is such that, [latex]P^{3} = P[/latex]. Then the eigenvalues of P are
solution: By Calyey Hamilton theorem, [latex]\lambda ^3=\lambda[/latex] [latex]\lambda =0, 1, -1[/latex]

question: Question 8 The solution of the differential equation, for [latex]t \gt 0, y''(t)+2y'(t)+y(t)=0[/latex] with initial conditions y(0) = 0 and y'(0) = 1, is (u(t) denotes the unit step function),
solution: The differentail equation is [latex]y'(t)+2y'(t)+y(t)=0[/latex] So, [latex] (s^2y(s)-sy(0)-y'(0))+2[sy(s)-y(0)]+y(s) =0[/latex] So,  [latex]y(s)=\frac{sy(0)+y'(0)+2y(0)}{s^2+2s+1}[/latex] Given that  [latex] y'(0)=1, y(0)=0 [/latex] So,  [latex]y(s)=\frac{1}{(s+1)^2} [/latex] So,  [latex]y(t)=te^{-t}u(t)[/latex]

question: Question 9 The value of the line integral [latex]\int_{c}(2xy^{2}dx+2x^{2}ydy+dz)[/latex] along a path joining the origin (0,0,0) and the point (1,1,1) is
solution: [latex]\int _C\bar{F}\cdot \bar{dr} [/latex] where, [latex]\bar{F}=xy^2\bar{i}+2x^2y\bar{j}+\bar{k} [/latex] [latex]\bigtriangledown \times \vec{F}=\vec{O} [/latex] [latex](\vec{F}[/latex] is irrotational [latex]\Rightarrow \vec{F}[/latex] is conservative) [latex]\begin{aligned} \vec{F}&=\bigtriangledown \phi \\ \phi _x&=2xy^2 \\ \phi _y&=2x^2y \\ \phi _z&= 1\\ \Rightarrow \; \phi &=x^2y^2+z+C \end{aligned}[/latex] where, [latex]\vec{F}[/latex] is conservative [latex]\int _C \bar{F}\bar{dr}=\int_{(0,0,0)}^{(1,1,1)}d\phi =[x^2y^2+z]_{(0,0,0)}^{(1,1,1,)}=2[/latex]

question: Question 10 Let f(x) be a real, periodic function satisfying f(-x)=-f(x). The general form of its Fourier series representation would be
solution: Given that, [latex]f(-x)=-f(x)[/latex] So, function is an odd function. So, the fourier series will have sine term only. So, [latex]f(x)=\sum_{k=1}^{\infty }b_x \sin (kx)[/latex]

question:
Question 11 A resistance and a coil are connected in series and supplied from a single phase, 100 V, 50 Hz ac source as shown in the figure below. The rms values of plausible voltages across the resistance ([latex]V_{R}[/latex])
and coil ([latex]V_{C}[/latex]) respectively, in volts, are
solution: As per GATE Official answer key MTA (Marks to All)

question: Question 12 The voltage (V) and current (A) across a load are as follows. [latex]v(t) = 100 sin(\omega t)[/latex], [latex]i(t) = 10 sin(\omega t - 60^{\circ}) + 2 sin(3\omega t) + 5 sin(5\omega t)[/latex]. The average power consumed by the load, in W, is___________.
solution: The average power consumed by the load = [latex]P=V_1I_1 \cos \phi [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{100}{\sqrt{2}}\frac{10}{\sqrt{2}} \cos 60^{\circ}=250W[/latex]

question: Question 13 A power system with two generators is shown in the figure below. The system (generators, buses and transmission lines) is protected by six overcurrent relays [latex]R_1 \; to \; R_6[/latex]. Assuming a mix of directional and nondirectional relays at appropriate locations, the remote backup relays for [latex]R_4[/latex] are
Question 14 A power system has 100 buses including 10 generator buses. For the load flow analysis using Newton-Raphson method in polar coordinates, the size of the Jacobian is
solution: Size of the Jacobian matrix is, [latex](2n-m-1)\times (2n-m-1)[/latex] Given that 10 generator buses, we need to assume with in the 10 buses one bus as slack bus the, [latex](2\times 100-10-1)\times (2\times 100-10-1)=189 \times 189[/latex]

question: Question 15 The inductance and capacitance of a 400 kV, three-phase, 50 Hz lossless transmission line are 1.6 mH/km/phase and 10 nF/km/phase respectively. The sending end voltage is maintained at 400 kV. To maintain a voltage of 400 kV at the receiving end, when the line is delivering 300 MW load, the shunt compensation required is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_n&=\sqrt{\frac{L}{C}} \\ &= \sqrt{\frac{1.6 \times10^{-3}}{10 \times 10^{-9}}}\\ &= 400\Omega \\ \text{SIL} &=\frac{400 \times 400}{400}=400 MW \end{aligned}[/latex] In the second case SIL decreases means [latex]Z_n[/latex] increasess. [latex]Z_n[/latex] increases with increase in inductance 'L'. So, it is inductive. Load [latex]\lt [/latex] SIL means, line behaves capacitive to compensate it inductor to be placed.

question: Question 16 A parallel plate capacitor filled with two dielectrics is shown in the figure below. If the electric field in the region A is 4 kV/cm, the electric field in the region B, in kV/cm, is
solution: As voltage is same across both the regions and distance between two plates is also same, then electric field remains same throughout the both region. As we know, [latex]E=\frac{V}{d}=[/latex] constant for both regions.

question: Question 17 A 50 MVA, 10 kV, 50 Hz, star-connected, unloaded three-phase alternator has a synchronous reactance of 1 p.u. and a sub-transient reactance of 0.2 p.u. If a 3-phase short circuit occurs close to the generator terminals, the ratio of initial and final values of the sinusoidal component of the short circuit current is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I''&=\frac{E_g}{X_d''};\; I=\frac{E_g}{X}\\ \frac{I''}{I}&=\frac{X}{X_d''}=\frac{1.0}{0.2}=5.0\; p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 18 Consider a linear time-invariant system with transfer function [latex]H(s)=\frac{1}{(s+1)}[/latex] If the input is cos(t) and the steady state output is [latex]A \cos (t+\alpha )[/latex], then the value of A is _________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} H(s)&=\frac{1}{(s+1)}\\ \text{Put, }s&=j\omega \\ H(j\omega)&=\frac{1}{j\omega+1}\\ |H(j\omega)|&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\omega ^2 +1}}\\ \because \; \text{ input }x(t)&=\cos (t)\\ \text{Here, } \omega &=1 \text{rad/sec}\\ \text{and }|x(t)|&=1\\ \text{hence, }&\text{steady state output}\\ y(t)&=|H(j\omega)|_{\omega=1} \cos (t+\angle H(j\omega)|_{\omega =1})\\ A&=|H(j\omega)|_{\omega =1}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=0.707 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 19 A three-phase diode bridge rectifier is feeding a constant DC current of 100 A to a highly inductive load. If three-phase, 415 V, 50 Hz AC source is supplying to this bridge rectifier then the rms value of the current in each diode, in ampere, is _____________.
solution: In the [latex]3-\phi[/latex] diode bridge rectifier each diode conducts for [latex]120^{\circ}[/latex] for one complete cycle. [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{Drms}&=\sqrt{\frac{1}{2 \pi}\int_{0}^{2\pi/3} I_0^2 d\omega t} \\ &= I_0\sqrt{\frac{2 \pi}{2 \pi \times 3}}\\ &= \frac{I_0}{\sqrt{3}}=\frac{100}{\sqrt{3}}=57.7A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 20 A buck-boost DC-DC converter, shown in the figure below, is used to convert 24 V battery voltage to 36 V DC voltage to feed a load of 72 W. It is operated at 20 kHz with an inductor of 2 mH and output capacitor of 1000 [latex]\mu[/latex]F. All devices are considered to be ideal. The peak voltage across the solid-state switch (S), in volt, is ____________.
solution: When switch 'S' is off, diode D is on then Therefore, Peak voltage across switch =24+36=60V

question: Question 21 For the network shown in the figure below, the frequency (in rad/s) at which the maximum phase lag occurs is, ___________.
Question 22 The direction of rotation of a single-phase capacitor run induction motor is reversed by
solution: Inter changing the terminals of the auxiliary winding.

options.A: interchanging the terminals of the AC supply
options.B: interchanging the terminals of the capacitor

question: Question 23 In the circuit shown below, the voltage and current sources are ideal. The voltage ([latex]V_{out}[/latex]) across the current source, in volts, is
solution: So, [latex]V_{out}=(5 \times 2 )+10=20V[/latex]

question: Question 24 The graph associated with an electrical network has 7 branches and 5 nodes. The number of independent KCL equations and the number of independent KVL equations, respectively, are
solution: Number of KCL equations = n-1=5-1=4 Number of KVL equations =b-(n-1) = 7-(5-1)=3

question:
Question 25 Two electrodes, whose cross-sectional view is shown in the figure below, are at the same potential.
The maximum electric field will be at the point
solution: At the point C, [latex]\bar{E}[/latex] (electric field intensity) is maximum being closest to the other plate.

question: Question 26 The Boolean expression [latex]\overline{(a+\bar{b}+c+\bar{d})+(b+\bar{c})}[/latex] simplifies to
solution: [latex]F=\overline{(a+\bar{b}+c+d)+(b+\bar{c})} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\overline{(a+\bar{b}+c+d)}\cdot \overline{(b+\bar{c})} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\bar{a}\cdot b\cdot \bar{c}\cdot d \cdot \bar{b} \cdot c [/latex] [latex]F=0[/latex]

question: Question 27 For the circuit shown below, taking the opamp as ideal, the output voltage [latex]V_{out}[/latex] in terms of the input voltages [latex]V_{1},V_{2} \; and \; V_{3}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]V_A=\left ( \frac{4}{5}V_1+\frac{1}{5}V_2 \right ) [/latex] [latex]V_{out}=-9V_3+10V_A [/latex] [latex]\;\;=-9V_3+8V_1+2V_2[/latex]

question: Question 28 Let [latex]x_{1}(t)\leftrightarrow X_{1}(\omega ) \; and \; x_{2}(t) \leftrightarrow X_{2}(\omega \omega )[/latex] be two signals whose Fourier Transforms are as shown in the figure below. In the figure, [latex]h(t)=e^{-2|t|}[/latex] denotes the impulse response. For the system shown above, the minimum sampling rate required to sample y(t), so that y(t) can be uniquely reconstructed from its samples, is
solution: Given that, Bandwidth of [latex]X_1(\omega )=B_1[/latex] Bandwidth of [latex]X_2(\omega )=B_2[/latex] system has [latex]h(t)=e^{-2|t|}[/latex] and input to the system is [latex]x_1(t) \cdot x_2(t)[/latex] The bandwidth of [latex]x_1(t) \cdot x_2(t)[/latex] is [latex]B_1+B_2[/latex]. The bandwidth of output will be [latex]B_1+B_2[/latex]. So, sampling rate will be [latex]2(B_1+B_2)[/latex].

question: Question 29 The value of the integral [latex]2\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }(\frac{sin 2\pi t}{\pi t})dt[/latex] is equal to
solution: The Fourier transform of [latex]\begin{aligned} &\frac{2 \sin (t\tau /2)}{t}\rightarrow 2 \pi \text{rect}\left ( \frac{\omega }{\tau } \right ) \\ &\frac{\sin (2 \pi t)}{\pi t}\rightarrow \text{rect} \left ( \frac{\omega }{4 \pi} \right )\\ &\text{So, }\int_{-\infty }^{\infty } \frac{\sin (2 \pi t)}{\pi t} e^{-j\omega t}dt=\text{rect}\left ( \frac{\omega }{4 \pi} \right )\\ &\text{Putting }\omega =0 \text{ in the above equation} \\ & \int_{-\infty }^{\infty } \frac{\sin (2 \pi t)}{\pi t} dt=1\\ &2\int_{-\infty }^{\infty } \frac{\sin (2 \pi t)}{\pi t} dt=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 30 Let y(x) be the solution of the differential equation [latex]\frac{d^{2}y}{dx^{2}}-4\frac{dy}{dx}+4y=0[/latex] with initial conditions y(0)=0 and [latex]\frac{dy}{dx}|_{x=0}=1[/latex]. Then the value of y(1) is _________.

Question 31 The line integral of the vector field [latex]F = 5xz \hat{i}+ (3x^{2} + 2y) \hat{j} + x^{2}z\hat{k}[/latex] along a path from (0,0,0) to (1,1,1) parametrized by (t, [latex]t^{2}[/latex], t) is _____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} E &=5xZ\bar{i}+(3x^2 +2y)\bar{j}+x^2z\bar{k} \\ &=\int _C \bar{F}\bar{d}r \\ &= \int _C 5xzdx +(3x^2+2y)dy +x^2zdz\\ x&=t, \; y=t^2,\; z=t,\; t=0 \; to \; 1 \\ dx&=dt \\ dy &=2tdt,\; dz =dt\\ &=\int_{0}^{1} 5t^2dt+(3t^2+2t^2)2tdt+t^3dt\\ &= \int_{0}^{1} (5t^2+11t^3)dt\\ &=\left [ \frac{5t^3}{3}+\frac{11t^4}{4} \right ]_0^1=\frac{5}{3}+\frac{11}{4}=4.41 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 32 Let [latex]P=\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1\\ 1&3 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]. Consider the set S of all vectors [latex]\binom{x}{y}[/latex] such that [latex]a^{2}+b^{2}=1[/latex] where [latex]\binom{a}{b} =P\binom{x}{y}[/latex]. Then S is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1\\ 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x\\ y \end{bmatrix}&=\begin{bmatrix} a\\ b \end{bmatrix} \\ 3x+y &=a \\ x+3y&=b \\ a^2+b^2&=1 \\ \Rightarrow \;\; 10x^2+10y^2+12xy &= 1 \end{aligned}[/latex] Ellipse with major axis along [latex]\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}[/latex].

options.C: an ellipse with major axis along [latex]\binom{1}{1}[/latex]
options.D: an ellipse with minor axis along [latex]\binom{1}{1}[/latex]

question: Question 33 Let the probability density function of a random variable, X, be given as: [latex]f_X(x)=\frac{3}{2}e^{-3x}u(x)+ae^{4x}u(-x)[/latex] where u(x) is the unit step function. Then the value of 'a' and [latex]Prob\{X\leq 0\}[/latex], respectively, are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f_x(x)&=\left\{\begin{matrix} ax^{4x} &x \lt 0 \\ \frac{3}{2}e^{-3x}& x\geq 0 \end{matrix}\right.\\ \int_{-\infty }^{\infty }f_x(x)&=1\\ \int_{-\infty }^{0}ax^{4x}dx+\int_{0}^{\infty }\frac{3}{2}e^{-3x}dx&=1\\ \left [ \frac{ax^{4x}}{4} \right ]_{-\infty }^0+\left [ \frac{\frac{3}{2}e^{-3x}}{-3} \right ]_0^\infty &=1\\ \frac{a}{3}+\frac{3}{6}&=1\\ a&=2\\ P(x\leq 0)&=\int_{-\infty }^{0}2e^{4x}dx \\ &=\left [ \frac{e^{4x}}{2} \right ]_{-\infty }^0=\frac{1}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 34 The driving point input impedance seen from the source [latex]V_s[/latex] of the circuit shown below, in [latex]\Omega[/latex], is ______.
solution: To find impedance seen by [latex]V_s [/latex] [latex]Z_s=\frac{V_s}{I_s} [/latex] [latex]V_1=2I_s[/latex] Applying KCL at node A, [latex]I_s=4V_1=\frac{V_A}{3}+\frac{V_A}{6}[/latex] [latex] V_A=V_s-V_1 [/latex] and  [latex]V_1=2I_s [/latex] So, [latex]I_s+8I_s=\frac{V_s-2I_s}{3}+\frac{V_s-2I_s}{6} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; 54I_s=2V_s-4I_s+V_s-2I_s [/latex] [latex]3V_s=60I_s [/latex] [latex]\frac{V_s}{I_s}=20\Omega[/latex]

question: Question 35 The z-parameters of the two port network shown in the figure are [latex]z_{11}=40\Omega ,z_{12}=60\Omega ,z_{21}=80\Omega [/latex]  and  [latex] z_{22}=100 \Omega[/latex]. The average power delivered to [latex]R_{L}=20\Omega[/latex], in watts, is _______.
solution: Given, [latex]Z_{11}=40\Omega ,Z_{12}=60\Omega [/latex] [latex]Z_{21}=80\Omega ,Z_{22}=100\Omega [/latex] From the figure, [latex]V_2=-20I_2\;\;...(i) [/latex] [latex]V_1=40I_1+60I_2\;\;...(ii)[/latex] [latex] V_2=80I_1+100I_2\;\;...(iii)[/latex] From equation (i) and (iii), we get [latex]-20I_2=80I_1+100I_2 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; I_2=-\frac{2}{3}I_1\;\;...(iv)[/latex] Using equation (ii) and (iv), we get [latex]V_1=40I_1+60I_2[/latex] [latex] \;\;=40I_1+60\left ( \frac{-2}{3} I_1\right ) [/latex] [latex]V_1=0[/latex] From the figure, [latex]20=10I_1+V_1 [/latex] Since,  [latex] V_1=0 [/latex] So, [latex]I_1=2A [/latex] [latex] I_2=\frac{-4}{3}A [/latex] Power dissipated in [latex]P_{R_L}=I_2^2R_L=\left ( \frac{4}{3} \right )^2 \times 20 [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{16}{9} \times 20=35.55W[/latex]

question: Question 36 In the balanced 3-phase, 50 Hz, circuit shown below, the value of inductance (L) is 10 mH. The value of the capacitance (C) for which all the line currents are zero, in millifarads, is ___________.
solution: Usingstar to delta conversion, Line current will be zero when the parallel pair of induction capacitor is resonant at f=50Hz So, [latex]50 \times 2\pi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{LC/3}} [/latex] [latex]100 \pi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{LC/3}} [/latex] Since, L=10mH C will be 3.03 mF.

question: Question 37 In the circuit shown below, the initial capacitor voltage is 4 V. Switch [latex]S_1[/latex] is closed at t=0. The charge (in [latex]\mu[/latex]C) lost by the capacitor from t=25[latex]\mu s[/latex] to t=100[latex]\mu s[/latex] is ____________.
solution: [latex]i(t)=\frac{4}{5}e^{-t/\tau }[/latex] [latex] \tau =RC [/latex] [latex]\;\;=20 \times 10^{-6}sec [/latex] Change lost by capacitor from [latex]t=25\mu s[/latex] to [latex]100\mu s[/latex] is [latex]\int_{25 \mu s}^{100\mu s}i(t)dt=6.99 \times 10^{-6}C[/latex]

question:
Question 38 The single line diagram of a balanced power system is shown in the figure. The voltage magnitude at the generator internal bus is constant and 1.0 p.u. The p.u. reactances of different components in the system are also shown in the figure. The infinite bus voltage magnitude is 1.0 p.u. A three phase
fault occurs at the middle of line 2. The ratio of the maximum real power that can be transferred during the pre-fault condition to the maximum real power that can be transferred under the faulted condition is _________.
solution: The ratio[latex]=\frac{P_1}{P_2}=\frac{X_1}{X_2}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} 1.\; \Rightarrow \; \;&\frac{j0.35 \times j0.6}{j1.2} &=j0.175 \\ 2.\; \Rightarrow \; \; &\frac{j0.6 \times j0.25}{j1.2} &=j0.125 \\ 3.\; \Rightarrow \; \; &\frac{j0.35 \times j0.25}{j1.2} &=j0.0729 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} X_{12}&=X_2\\ &=j0.375+j0.125+\frac{j0.375\times j0.125}{j0.0729}\\ &=j1.1430\;p.u.\\ \frac{P_1}{P_2}&=\frac{X_2}{X_1}=\frac{j1.1430}{j0.5}=2.286 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 39 The open loop transfer function of a unity feedback control system is given by [latex]G(s)=\frac{K(s+1)}{s(1+Ts)(1+2s)}, K\gt 0,T \gt 0[/latex] The closed loop system will be stable if,
solution: Open loop transfer function: [latex]G(s)=\frac{K(s+1)}{s(1+Ts)(1+2s)};[/latex]  [latex] \; K \gt 0 \; [/latex] and [latex]\; t \gt 0[/latex] For closed loop system stability, characteristic equation is, [latex]1+G(s)H(s)=0[/latex] [latex] 1+\frac{K(s+1)}{s(1+Ts)(1+2s)}\cdot 1=0[/latex] [latex] s(1+Ts)(1+2s)+K(s+1)=0 [/latex] [latex]2Ts^3+(2+T)s^2+(1+K)s+K=0 [/latex] Using Routh's criteria, For stability, [latex]K \gt 0[/latex] and  [latex] (2+T)(1+K)-2TK \gt 0 [/latex] [latex]K(2+T-2T)+(2+T) \gt 0 [/latex] or [latex] -(T-2)K+2(2+T) \gt 0 [/latex] [latex]-K \gt -\frac{(2+T)}{(T-2)}[/latex] or  [latex] K \lt \frac{T+2}{(T-2)} [/latex] Hence for stability, [latex]0 \lt K \lt \frac{T+2}{T-2}[/latex]

question:
Question 40 At no load condition, a 3-phase, 50 Hz, lossless power transmission line has sending-end and
receiving-end voltages of 400 kV and 420 kV respectively. Assuming the velocity of traveling wave to be the velocity of light, the length of the line, in km, is ____________.
solution: At no load, [latex]\begin{aligned} V_s&=AV_R\\ 400 &=A420\\ A&=\frac{400}{420}=0.9524\\ A&=1+\frac{YZ}{2}\\ &=1+\frac{(r+j\omega L)()g+j\omega C)}{2}\\ &\text{For lossless line,}\\ r&=0,g=0\\ \text{then,}\\ A&=1-\frac{(\omega C)(\omega L)}{2}\\ \beta l&=\sqrt{\omega L\omega C}\\ A&=0.9524=1-\frac{\beta ^2l^2}{2}\\ \beta l&=0.3085\\ \beta &=\frac{0.3085}{l}\\ \frac{V}{f}&=\frac{2\pi}{\beta }\\ \frac{3 \times 10^5}{50}&=\frac{2 \pi}{\left ( \frac{0.3085}{l} \right )}\\ l&=294.52km \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 The power consumption of an industry is 500 kVA, at 0.8 p.f. lagging. A synchronous motor is added to raise the power factor of the industry to unity. If the power intake of the motor is 100 kW, the p.f. of the motor is _____________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_1 &= 500 \times 0.8=400kW\\ Q_1&= 500 \times 0.6=300kVAR \end{aligned}[/latex] The power factor is to be raised to unity The motor has to supply 300kVAR The motor rating is 100 kW, 300kVAR [latex] \begin{aligned} \phi _m &=\tan ^{-1}\left ( \frac{Q}{P} \right ) \\ \phi _m&= \tan^{-1}\left ( \frac{300}{100} \right ) =71.56 \end{aligned} [/latex] Power factor of motor [latex]= \cos \phi _m=\cos 71.56=0.316[/latex]

question: Question 42 The flux linkage ([latex]\lambda[/latex]) and current (i) relation for an electromagnetic system is [latex]\lambda = (\sqrt{i})/g[/latex]. When i=2A and g (air-gap length)=10cm, the magnitude of mechanical force on the moving part, in N, is ________.
solution: Energy in magnetic system, [latex]\begin{aligned} W_f &= \int_{0}^{\lambda } i(\lambda )\; d\lambda \\ \because \;\; i &=\lambda ^2g^2 \\ W_f &= \int_{0}^{\lambda } \lambda ^2g^2 \; d\lambda \\ &=g^2\frac{\lambda ^3}{2} \end{aligned} [/latex] Now, mechanical force, [latex]\begin{aligned} F_F &=-\frac{\partial W_f (\lambda ,g)}{\partial g} \\ &=-\frac{\partial }{\partial g} \left ( \frac{g^2\lambda ^3}{3} \right )\\ &= -\frac{2}{3}\lambda ^3 g\\ \because \;\; i=2, \;g&=10cm ,\; \lambda =10\sqrt{2} \\ \text{Hence,}\;\;|F_F|&=\frac{2}{3} \times (10\sqrt{2})^3 \times 0.1\\ &=188.56N \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 43 The starting line current of a 415 V, 3-phase, delta connected induction motor is 120 A, when the rated voltage is applied to its stator winding. The starting line current at a reduced voltage of 110 V,
in ampere, is _________.
solution: 415V, 3-phase,  [latex]\Delta[/latex] connected induction motor [latex](I_{st})_{line}=120A[/latex] at rated voltage. at, V=110V, i.e. reduced voltage [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{st} &=x(I_{st})_{rated} \\ \text{where}\;\; x&= \frac{V_{reduced}}{V_{rated}}\\ &=\frac{110}{415} \\ (I_{st})_{at \; 110V} &= \left ( \frac{110}{415} \right )\times 120\\ &=31.807A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 44 A single-phase, 2 kVA, 100/200 V transformer is reconnected as an auto-transformer such that its kVA rating is maximum. The new rating, in kVA, is ______.
solution: 2 kVA, 100/200 V transformer, [latex]\begin{aligned} A_{2 winding} &=\frac{200}{100}=2 \\ [(kVA)_{auto}]_{max} &= (a_{2winding}+1)(kVA)_{2winding} \\ &=(2+1) \times 2 =6 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 45 A full-bridge converter supplying an RLE load is shown in figure. The firing angle of the bridge converter is 120[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. The supply voltage [latex]v_{m}(t) = 200\pi sin (100 \pi t) V [/latex], [latex]R=20 \Omega[/latex], E=800 V. The inductor L is large enough to make the output current [latex]I_L[/latex] a smooth dc current. Switches are lossless. The real power fed back to the source, in kW, is __________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_0&=2\frac{V_m}{\pi}\cos \alpha \\ &=2\frac{200 \pi}{\pi} \cos 120^{\circ}\\ V_0&=-200V\\ |V_0|&=200V\\ &\text{Power balance equation}\\ EI_0&=I_0^2 R+V_0I_0\\ 800I_0&=I_0^2(20)+200I_0\\ I+0&=30A\\ &\text{Power fed to source}\\ &=V_0I_0\\ &=200 \times 30\\ &=6kW \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 46 A three-phase Voltage Source Inverter (VSI) as shown in the figure is feeding a delta connected resistive load of 30 [latex]\Omega[/latex]/phase. If it is fed from a 600 V battery, with 180[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] conduction of solid-state devices, the power consumed by the load, in kW, is __________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_L&=V_{ph}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}V_s\\ V_{ph}&=\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}} \times 600\\ P&=3\frac{V_{ph}^2}{R}=\frac{3 \times \frac{2}{3} \times 600^2}{30}\\ &=24kW \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 47 A DC-DC boost converter, as shown in the figure below, is used to boost 360V to 400 V, at a power of 4 kW. All devices are ideal. Considering continuous inductor current, the rms current in
the solid state switch (S), in ampere, is _________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{V_0}{V_s}&=\frac{1}{1-\alpha } \\ \frac{400}{360}&= \frac{1}{1-\alpha }\\ \alpha &= 0.1\\ V_sI_s&= \text{Power}\\ 360I_s &=4000\\ I_s&=11.1A \end{aligned}[/latex] Neglecting ripple in [latex]i_s[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{\text{switch (rms)}}&=I_s\left ( \frac{T_{on}}{T} \right )^{1/2}\\ &=I_s\sqrt{\alpha }\\ &=11.1\sqrt{0.1}=3.5A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 48 A single-phase bi-directional voltage source converter (VSC) is shown in the figure below. All devices are ideal. It is used to charge a battery at 400 V with power of 5 kW from a source [latex]V_s[/latex]=220 V (rms), 50 Hz sinusoidal AC mains at unity p.f. If its AC side interfacing inductor is 5 mH and the switches are operated at 20 kHz, then the phase shift ([latex]\delta[/latex]) between AC mains voltage ([latex]V_s[/latex]) and fundamental AC rms VSC voltage ([latex]V_{c1}[/latex]), in degree, is _________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P&=V_sI_s \;p.f.\\ 5 \times 10^3 &= 220 \times I_s \times 1\\ I_s&=22.72A\\ \tan \delta &=\frac{I_s X_s}{V_s}\\ \delta &=\tan^{-1}\left ( \frac{I_sX_s}{V_s} \right )\\ \delta &=\tan^{-1}\left ( \frac{22.72 \times 2 \pi \times 50 \times 5 \times 10^{-3}}{220} \right )\\ \delta &=9.21^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 49 Consider a linear time invariant system [latex]\dot{x}=Ax[/latex], with initial condition [latex]x(0)[/latex] at t=0. Suppose [latex]\alpha \; and \; \beta[/latex] are eigenvectors of (2 x 2) matrix A corresponding to distinct eigenvalues [latex]\lambda_{1} \; and \;  \lambda _{2}[/latex] respectively. Then the response [latex]x(t)[/latex] of the system due to initial condition [latex]x(0)=\alpha[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\dot{x}=Ax[/latex] Eigen values are [latex]\lambda _1[/latex] and [latex]\lambda _2[/latex] we can write, [latex]\phi (t)=\begin{bmatrix} e^{\lambda _1 t} & 0\\ 0& e^{\lambda _2 t} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] Response due to initial conditions, [latex]x(t)=\phi (t)x(0) [/latex] [latex]x(t)=\begin{bmatrix} e^{\lambda _1 t} & 0\\ 0& e^{\lambda _2 t} \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} \alpha \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex]=\alpha e^{\lambda _1 t}[/latex]

question: Question 50 A second-order real system has the following properties: a) the damping ratio [latex]\xi[/latex] = 0.5 and undamped natural frequency [latex]\omega _{n}[/latex]=10 rad/s, b) the steady state value of the output, to a unit step input, is 1.02. The transfer function of the system is
solution: Damping ratio  [latex]\xi=0.5[/latex] Undamped natural frequency [latex]\omega _n=10[/latex]  rad/sec Steady state output toa unit step input [latex]C_{ss}=1.02[/latex] Hence steady state error [latex]e_{ss}=1.02-1.00=0.02[/latex] [latex] \because[/latex] Characteristic equation is, [latex]s^2+2 \xi \omega _ns+\omega _n^2=0 [/latex] [latex]s^2+2 \times 0.5\times 10 s+100=0 [/latex] [latex]s^2+10s+100=0[/latex] From options, if we take option (B) then [latex] C_{ss}=\lim_{s \to 0}s\cdot C(s) [/latex] [latex]\;\; \; \; \;=\lim_{s \to 0 }s \times \frac{1}{s} \times \frac{102}{s^2+10s+100} [/latex] [latex]C_{ss}=1.02[/latex] Hence, Option (B) is correct answer.

question: Question 51 Three single-phase transformers are connected to form a delta-star three-phase transformer of 110 kV/ 11 kV. The transformer supplies at 11 kV a load of 8 MW at 0.8 p.f. lagging to a nearby plant. Neglect the transformer losses. The ratio of phase currents in delta side to star side is
solution: At, 100 kV, load is 8 MW, 0.8 p.f. lagging [latex]\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \;\; \frac{(V_{ph})_{\Delta }}{(V_{ph})_{Y}} &= \frac{(I_{ph})_{Y}}{(I_{ph})_{\Delta }}\\ \Rightarrow \;\; (I_{ph})_{\Delta } &= (I_{ph})_Y \times \frac{(V_{ph})_{Y}}{(V_{ph})_{\Delta }} \\ \frac{(I_{ph})_{\Delta }}{(V_{ph})_{Y}}&=\frac{11\sqrt{3}}{110}=1:10\sqrt{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 52 The gain at the breakaway point of the root locus of a unity feedback system with open loop transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{Ks}{(s-1)(s-4)}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]OLTS\Rightarrow G(s)=\frac{Ks}{(s-1)(s-4)}[/latex] Now, characteristic equation, [latex]1+G(s)H(s)=0[/latex] [latex] \frac{Ks}{(s-1)(s-4)}+1=0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;\; Ks+(s^2-5s+4)=0 [/latex] [latex]\;\;K=-\frac{(s^2-5s+4)}{s}=\left [ s-5+\frac{4}{s} \right ][/latex] For break away point [latex]: \frac{dK}{ds}=0[/latex] [latex] \frac{dK}{ds}=-\left [ 1-0-\frac{4}{s^2} \right ]=0 [/latex] We get, [latex]s=\pm 2[/latex] Therefore valid break away point is s=2 Now gain at s=2 is K=(Product of distances from all the poles to break away point)/(Product of distances from all the zero to break away point) Gain, [latex]K=\frac{1 \times 2}{2}=1[/latex]

question: Question 53 Two identical unloaded generators are connected in parallel as shown in the figure. Both the generators are having positive, negative and zero sequence impedances of j0.4 p.u., j0.3 p.u. and j0.15 p.u., respectively. If the pre-fault voltage is 1 p.u., for a line-to-ground (L-G) fault at the terminals of the generators, the fault current, in p.u., is ___________.
Question 54 An energy meter, having meter constant of 1200 revolutions/kWh, makes 20 revolutions in 30 seconds for a constant load. The load, in kW, is _____________.
solution: [latex]P_{loss}=\frac{20 \times 3600}{1200 \times 30}=2kW[/latex]

question:
Question 55 A rotating conductor of 1 m length is placed in a radially outward (about the z-axis) magnetic flux
density (B) of 1 Tesla as shown in figure below. Conductor is parallel to and at 1 m distance from the z-axis. The speed of the conductor in r.p.m. required to induce a voltage of 1 V across it, should
be __________.
solution: Voltage insuced [latex]=\int_{0}^{1}E_m \cdot dt[/latex] (where [latex]E_m[/latex] is induced electric field) Since, Volatage induced =1 V So,  [latex]E_m[/latex] = 1 V/m As we know, [latex]E_m=\bar{V} \times \bar{B}[/latex] where, V= (radius of path) x (angular velocity) [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{1V}{m} &=(V \times 1 \; \text{Tesla}) \\ V&=1 \; m/sec \\ V&= r \times \omega =1 \; m/sec\\ \text{Since, } r&=1m, \; \text{So }\omega =1 \; \text{rad/sec} \end{aligned}[/latex] Now from this we get [latex]\begin{aligned} \omega &=2 \times \pi \times \frac{N}{60}=1 \; \text{rad/sec}\\ N&=\frac{30}{\pi}=9.55 \; \text{revolutions per minute} \end{aligned}[/latex]
